message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a non-cystic cold nodule requires fine needle aspiration, and the high level of calcitonin suggests medullary thyroid carcinoma. This cancer is associated with RET gene mutations, making option (B) the correct answer. MEN1 gene mutations are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia, but not specifically with thyroid cancer. Loss of function of PPARɣ is associated with insulin resistance and diabetes, and activating mutations of BRAF receptor are associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high calcitonin level suggests medullary thyroid carcinoma, which is associated with RET gene mutations. Therefore, a RET gene mutation would warrant thyroidectomy in this patient. MEN1 gene mutation is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1, which can involve the thyroid but is not specific to thyroid cancer. Loss of function of PPARɣ is associated with insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes, but not with thyroid cancer. Activating mutation of the BRAF receptor is associated with papillary thyroid cancer, but not necessarily an indication for thyroidectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a family history of thyroid cancer, and his calcitonin levels are elevated, suggesting medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). RET gene mutations are associated with MTC and warrant thyroidectomy. MEN1 gene mutations are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1, but it is not specifically associated with MTC. Loss of function of PPARɣ is associated with metabolic syndrome but not thyroid cancer. Activating mutations of the BRAF receptor are associated with papillary thyroid cancer but not necessarily MTC.

We refer to PubMed Central for help. The patient's symptoms and family history are suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma, which is associated with RET gene mutations. Therefore, RET gene mutation would warrant thyroidectomy in this patient. MEN1 gene mutation is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia, but it is not specific to thyroid cancer. A loss of function of PPARɣ and activating mutation of the BRAF receptor are not associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a family history of thyroid cancer and a high calcitonin level, which suggests a possible medullary thyroid carcinoma. The RET gene mutation is commonly associated with this condition and warrants thyroidectomy. MEN1 gene mutation is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 and may require thyroidectomy if there is a concurrent thyroid tumor. Loss of function of PPARγ is associated with insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome. Activating mutation of the BRAF receptor is commonly associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma, which may not always require thyroidectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a solid nodule along with a family history of thyroid cancer and a high level of calcitonin strongly suggests medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTC is linked to RET gene mutations, so thyroidectomy is warranted in this patient. MEN1 gene mutation is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia, but MTC is not a typical manifestation. Loss of function of PPARɣ is not associated with thyroid cancer, and activating mutation of the BRAF receptor is associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma but not MTC.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s high calcitonin level suggests a possible medullary thyroid carcinoma which is associated with RET gene mutations. Thus, a RET gene mutation would warrant thyroidectomy in this patient. MEN1 gene mutation is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1, which includes tumors in the pancreas and parathyroid glands. A loss of function of PPARɣ is associated with insulin resistance and obesity. Activating mutation of the BRAF receptor is associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma, but not necessarily a need for thyroidectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's family history of thyroid cancer and the high calcitonin level suggests a diagnosis of medullary thyroid cancer, which is associated with RET gene mutations. Therefore, a RET gene mutation would warrant thyroidectomy in this patient. The other genetic mutations listed are not associated with medullary thyroid cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a family history of thyroid cancer, a non-cystic cold nodule, and an elevated calcitonin level suggests a possible medullary thyroid carcinoma, which is associated with the RET gene mutation. MEN1 gene mutation is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1, but it is not typically associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma. Loss of function of PPARɣ is associated with a type of thyroid cancer called follicular thyroid cancer, but not medullary thyroid carcinoma. Activating mutation of the BRAF receptor is common in papillary thyroid carcinoma, but not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The family history and calcitonin level suggest medullary thyroid cancer, which is associated with RET gene mutation. Thyroidectomy is recommended for those with this mutation to prevent metastasis. The other options are not associated with medullary thyroid cancer.
